questions.question: What do the letters CDM stand for?

options.A: Control of Demolition and Management Regulations

questions.explanation: The CDM Regulations impose duties to manage construction projects, ensure physical safeguards are provided to prevent danger during such projects and that adequate welfare facilities are provided.

questions.question: Identify one method of enforcing regulations that are available to the Health and Safety Executive:
questions.explanation: Improvement notices require action to achieve standards which meet health and safety law.

questions.question: What happens if a Prohibition Notice is issued by an Inspector of the local authority or the HSE?

options.A: The work in hand can be completed, but no new work started
options.B: The work can continue if adequate safety precautions are put in place
options.C: The work that is subject to the notice must cease
options.D: The work can continue, provided a risk assessment is carried out

questions.explanation: The work activity covered by a prohibition notice must cease, until the identified danger is removed.

questions.question: Health and Safety Executive Inspector can?

options.A: Only visit if they have made an appointment
options.C: Only visit if accompanied by the principal contractor
options.D: Only visit to interview the site manager

questions.explanation: Inspectors have a range of powers, including the right to visit premises at any time.

questions.question: Prohibition Notice means:

options.A: When you finish the work you must not start again
options.C: Work is to stop for that day only
options.D: Work may continue until the end of the day

questions.explanation: The work activity covered by the prohibition notice must cease, until the identified danger is removed.

questions.question: In what circumstances can an HSE Improvement Notice be issued?

options.A: If there is a breach of legal requirements
options.C: Only between Monday and Friday on site

questions.explanation: Improvement notices require action to achieve standards which meet health and safety law.

questions.question: What is an Improvement Notice?

options.A: A notice issued by the site principal contractor to tidy up the site
options.B: A notice from the client to the principal contractor to speed up the work
options.C: A notice issued by a Building Control Officer to deepen foundations
options.D: A notice issued by an HSE/local authority Inspector to enforce compliance with health and safety legislation

questions.explanation: Improvement notices require action to achieve standards which meet health and safety law.

questions.question: If a Health and Safety Executive Inspector issues a Prohibition Notice, this means that:

options.A: The Site Manager can choose whether or not to ignore the notice
options.B: Specific work activities, highlighted on the notice, must stop
options.C: The HSE must supervise the work covered by the notice
options.D: The HSE must supervise all work from then on

questions.explanation: Prohibition notices are intended to stop activities which can cause serious injury.

questions.question: Employers are required to provide information to their employees on their health and safety rights and responsibilities and how to get advice by:

options.A: Telling them verbally when they start work for them
options.B: Displaying a poster or giving them leaflets approved by the HSE
options.C: Making them read the company health and safety policy

questions.explanation: This is a requirement of the Health and Safety Information for Employees Regulations (as amended).

questions.question: Who is responsible for signing a Company Safety Policy?
questions.explanation: The Health and Safety at Work Act requires the most senior member of management to sign the health and safety policy statement.

questions.question: Which one of the following must be in a company's written Health and Safety Policy?

options.A: Aims and objectives of the company
options.B: Organisation and arrangements in force for carrying out the health and safety policy
options.C: Name of the Health and Safety Adviser

questions.explanation: This is a specific requirement of the Health and Safety at Work Act.

questions.question: Employers have to produce a written Health and Safety Policy statement when:

options.B: They employ five people or more

questions.explanation: This is a specific requirement of the Health and Safety at Work Act.

questions.question: Companies employing five or more people must have a written Health and Safety Policy because:

options.A: The principal contractor gives them work on site
options.C: The Social Security Act requires it

questions.question: What do the letters HSE stand for?
questions.explanation: The Health and Safety Executive was established under the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974.

questions.question: The Health and Safety Executive is:

options.A: Part of the National Health Service
options.B: The regulatory body for the promotion of health and safety at work
options.C: The jury in health and safety court cases

questions.explanation: The Health and Safety Executive is part of the Department for Work and Pensions.

questions.question: The Health and Safety at Work Act requires employers to provide what for their employees?
questions.explanation: This is a specific requirement of Section 2 of the Health and Safety at Work Act.

questions.question: The Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 and any regulations made under the Act are:

options.A: Not compulsory, but should be complied with if convenient
options.C: Practical advice for the employer to follow

questions.explanation: The requirements of health and safety law are mandatory and failure to follow them can lead to prosecution.

questions.question: Under the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974, which of the following have a duty to work safely?
questions.explanation: Employers, employees and the self-employed all have duties to work safely under the Act.

questions.question: What is the MAXIMUM penalty that a Higher Court, can currently impose for a breach of the Health and Safety at Work Act?

options.D: Unlimited fine and two years' imprisonment

questions.explanation: A Lower Court can impose a fine of up to £20,000 and/or up to six months imprisonment for certain offences. The potential fine in a Higher Court, however, is unlimited and the term of imprisonment can be up to 2 years.

questions.question: What do the letters ACOP stand for?
questions.explanation: An ACOP is a code of practice approved by the Health and Safety Executive (or the Health and Safety Commission prior to April 2008).

questions.question: Where should you look for official advice on health and safety matters?

options.A: A set of health and safety guidelines provided by suppliers
options.B: The health and safety rules as laid down by the employer
options.C: Guidance issued by the Health and Safety Executive
options.D: A professionally approved guide book on regulations

questions.explanation: The HSE is the UK enforcing body and its guidance can be regarded as 'official'.

questions.question: Regulations that govern health and safety on construction sites:

options.B: Do not apply during 'out of hours' working

questions.explanation: The requirements of health and safety law are mandatory, and failure to follow them can lead to prosecutions.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The duty for health and safety falls only on the employer
options.B: All employees must take reasonable care, not only to protect themselves but also their colleagues
options.C: Employees have no responsibility for Health and Safety on site
options.D: Only the client is responsible for safety on site

questions.explanation: This is a legal requirement under Section 7 of the Health & Safety at Work Act.

questions.question: Who of the following would you expect to be responsible for managing health and safety on site?
questions.explanation: The responsibility for management of health and safety at work rests with the employer.

questions.question: Which of the following is correct for risk assessment?

options.A: It is a good idea but not essential
options.B: Only required to be done for hazardous work

questions.explanation: There is a legal requirement for all work to be suitably risk assessed.

questions.question: In the context of a risk assessment, what do you understand by the term risk?

options.B: Something with the potential to cause injury
options.C: Any work activity that can be described as dangerous
options.D: The likelihood that harm from a particular hazard will occur

questions.explanation: Hazard and risk are not the same. Risk reflects the chance of being harmed by a hazard.

questions.question: Who would you expect to carry out a risk assessment on your working site?
questions.explanation: A risk assessment must be conducted by a 'competent person'.

questions.question: What is a HAZARD?

options.A: Where an accident is likely to happen
options.C: Something with the potential to cause harm
options.D: The likelihood of something going wrong

questions.explanation: Examples of hazards include: a drum of acid, breeze blocks on an elevated plank; cables running across a floor.

questions.question: What must be done before any work begins?
questions.explanation: This is a legal requirement of the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations.

questions.question: Complete the following sentence: A risk assessment:

options.A: Is a piece of paper required by law
options.C: Is a means of analysing what might go wrong

questions.explanation: Risk assessment involves a careful review of what can cause harm and the practical measures to be taken to reduce the risk of harm.

questions.question: Why would your supervisor ask you to read the method statement and risk assessment before you start your next job?

options.A: They think you have got nothing better to do
options.B: The documents contain information on how to carry out the job in a safe manner
options.C: They wouldn't as they think they are a waste of time
options.D: As someone has taken the time and trouble to write them, you might as well read them

questions.explanation: The supervisor must, by law, keep workers advised of significant risks, and control measures.

questions.question: What do the blue and white health and safety signs tell you?

options.B: Where the nearest fire exit is

questions.explanation: Blue and white signs show a 'mandatory' requirement.

questions.question: What colours are emergency exit signs?
questions.explanation: The colours are prescribed in the Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations.

questions.question: What is the main colour on a safety sign stating that you must NOT do something?
questions.explanation: Prohibitory signs are round and feature a black pictogram on a white background with red edging and diagonal line.

questions.question: The Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations require the colour coding of signs. What colours are used on a sign indicating a warning, for example 'Fork-lift trucks operating'?
questions.explanation: Warning signs are triangular and feature a black pictogram on a yellow background with black edging.

questions.question: The Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations require the colour coding of safety signs. What colours are used on a sign indicating a prohibited activity, for example 'No access for pedestrians'?
questions.explanation: Prohibitory signs are round and feature a black pictogram on a white background with red edging and diagonal line.

questions.question: The Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations require the colour coding of safety signs. What colours are used on a sign indicating a mandatory activity, for example 'Safety helmets must be worn'?
questions.explanation: Mandatory signs are round and feature a white pictogram on a blue background.

questions.question: The Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations require the colour coding of safety signs. What colours are used on a sign indicating a safe condition, for example First Aid kit?
questions.explanation: Emergency escape and first-aid signs are rectangular or square and feature a white pictogram on a green background.

questions.question: Why should regular inspections of the workplace take place?

options.A: To check whether the working environment is safe
options.B: To check that all employees are present
options.C: To check that everyone is doing their job
options.D: To prepare for a visit from an HSE Inspector

questions.explanation: The Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations require that routine inspections of workplaces are carried out to ensure that preventative and protective measures are in place and effective.

questions.question: How can you help to prevent accidents?

options.B: Know how to get help quickly
options.D: Know where the first-aid kit is kept

questions.explanation: Action to improve safety can only be taken if the risk is known about. Employees have a duty of care to other employees.
